awd_titl_txt: Using Velocity Fields to Improve Gravitational Lensing Mass Measurements of Galaxies and Galaxy Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
The mass content of galaxies and clusters of galaxies is difficult to measure if the matter is not emitting light. One way of measuring this mass is by looking at distortions in the shapes of more distant galaxies as their light is deflected by the gravitational influence of the mass in the galaxy or cluster of interest. This project will test to see if looking for distortions in the velocities of the stars in the distant galaxies can help improve these measurements. The project will use simulations to see what improvements can be made using the new technique.

Current weak lensing surveys require large numbers of lensed galaxies to be averaged in order to beat down the noise in measurements of lensing mass. This project will look at the benefits of including measurements of the velocity field of the lensed galaxies. This should reduce the number of galaxies needed to obtain the same signal-to-noise, and therefore increase the angular resolution of the mass distributions that can be measured using weak lensing. The project will use cosmological simulations to assess the efficacy of this technique and identify ways to maximize the return on observational investment in weak lensing surveys.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Einstein predicted that the path of a light ray from a distant star would be bent the gravity of a massive object. This prediction was famously confirmed in 1919 and led to the field we know today as gravitational lensing, which allows us to map dark matter. Astronomers measure the mass of a "lens" galaxy (including its dark matter) by measuring the bending of light from a more distant "source" galaxy behind it. This project assessed the feasibility of a proposed new method (called the velocity-field method) to make these measurements much more precise, which could in turn enable astronomers to map dark matter much more precisely.


Intellectual merit: we used a two-prong approach. First, we used a method called Fisher Information to forecast how precise the velocity-field approach would be under ideal conditions (meaning each source galaxy is a flat disk without complicating factors such as satellite galaxies, a disk that's not exactly flat, etc). We found that the velocity-field approach is indeed very promising in this limit, so we continued to the second prong: analyzing mock data from simulated galaxies. This is useful because the simulations do include the complications mentioned above (satellite galaxies, warped disks, etc) but do not include lensing. Therefore, if we "observe" these simulated galaxies and run the data through our data analysis code, the code should find zero lensing. Any nonzero conclusion is a quantitative measure of how imperfect the velocity-field method would be if applied to real data.


Substantial amounts of work went into (i) generating mock data from the simulated galaxies, that is similar to the quality of data obtainable on real galaxies; and (ii) writing a data analysis code that, given a data set, extracts a measurement of the lensing.  Then we analyzed mock data from hundreds of simulated galaxies. The results are broken into two categories: lensing that stretches or compresses the apparent major or minor axis of the source galaxy (denoted gamma_+) and lensing that stretches or compresses at +-45 degrees from these axes (gamma_x).


We found that precise gamma_+ measurements will be impossible, because the gamma_+ measurement process depends on the assumption that the galaxy's disk is circular when viewed face-on. The simulated galaxies deviated from circularity (intrinsically, before lensing) enough to inject a great deal of uncertainty into any inference of gamma_+.  We then researched everything known about the intrinsic circularity of disk galaxies in nature, and this conclusion was confirmed: they are just not circular enough to make this method work.


On the other hand we found that gamma_x inference, which does not depend on the intrinsic circularity of galaxies, worked reasonably well. It didn't work as well as the Fisher method predicted it would, and perhaps not well enough to transform the way lensing measurements are done, but there are reasons to suspect that the method can still be improved enough to be very impactful. Specifically, we had to write a very complicated data analysis code to simultaneously infer gamma_+ and gamma_x.  If we drop the objective of inferring gamma_+ we can write a far simpler, perhaps more robust and precise, code to infer gamma_x alone.  Specifically, we can focus entirely on the asymmetry of the galaxy (symmetry is disturbed by gamma_x but not gamma_+) without having to create a complicated model of the galaxy. It is our hope that this new approach (which will have to be implemented and tested outside the scope of this award) will yield robust and precise gamma_x measurements.


Broader impacts: we ran a graduate admissions "bootcamp" to inform undergraduates what graduate school is and advise them on how to navigate the applications process.  The key feature of this camp is that we try to reach students who really need this information and advice, rather than simply give a boost to the students who are already well-prepared.  We ask faculty from all over California, especially at 4-year campuses with no graduate programs, to recruit their students who could benefit; we pay for food and lodging to remove financial barriers; and we convene a panel of current graduate students to provide down-to-earth advice rather than have administrators present a rosy picture. The camp served 50-60 students in 2019 when it was in-person, and about 30 in each of the following two years when it was online due to the pandemic.
